        I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <span class="line"><!---->I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <!----></span>https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1"><!---->https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<!----></a> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <span class="line"><!----> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <!----></span><br>There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <span class="line"><!---->There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<!----></a> ).<span class="line"><!----> ).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        That is very  disappointing, I added a comment on Stackoverflow but you are basically blocking developers from testing on Chrome. I am currently forced to use Firefox and I cannot test my software on Chrome<span class="line"><!---->That is very  disappointing, I added a comment on Stackoverflow but you are basically blocking developers from testing on Chrome. I am currently forced to use Firefox and I cannot test my software on Chrome<!----></span><br><br>Here is why <span class="line"><!---->Here is why <!----></span><br>1 - Chrome behaves differently from other browsers. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <span class="line"><!---->1 - Chrome behaves differently from other browsers. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <!----></span><br>2- you assume developers have always control over their development environments and thus what certificate is used and how it is provisioned. This is not the case. Developers need to allow self-signed certificates or they will just use another browser and will not be able to test local changes on Chrome. <span class="line"><!---->2- you assume developers have always control over their development environments and thus what certificate is used and how it is provisioned. This is not the case. Developers need to allow self-signed certificates or they will just use another browser and will not be able to test local changes on Chrome. <!----></span><br>3 - It is inconsistent that self-signed checks allows users to override them but not for the HSTS one. Why can users just click and ignore self-signed certificates warning when HSTS is disabled vs when it is not?<span class="line"><!---->3 - It is inconsistent that self-signed checks allows users to override them but not for the HSTS one. Why can users just click and ignore self-signed certificates warning when HSTS is disabled vs when it is not?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It's unclear to me what the issue is here. If<span class="line"><!---->It's unclear to me what the issue is here.         I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <span class="line"><!---->I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <!----></span>https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1"><!---->https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<!----></a> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <span class="line"><!----> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <!----></span><br>There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <span class="line"><!---->There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<!----></a> ).<span class="line"><!----> ).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

I am currently forced to use Firefox and I cannot test my software on Chrome<span class="line"><!---->That is very  disappointing, I added a comment on Stackoverflow but you are basically blocking developers from testing on Chrome. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <span class="line"><!---->1 - Chrome behaves differently from other browsers. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <!----></span><br>2- you assume developers have always control over their development environments and thus what certificate is used and how it is provisioned. This is not the case.         hi Carlo, thanks for checking this.<span class="line"><!---->hi Carlo, thanks for checking this.<!----></span><br><br>The main domain replies with header max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload as described at point 1.<span class="line"><!---->The main domain replies with header max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload as described at point 1.<!----></span><br><br>At point 3 I am stuck because  Chrome does not let me the end user of the browser to override the policy as it does when there is a self-signed certificate.<span class="line"><!---->At point 3 I am stuck because  Chrome does not let me the end user of the browser to override the policy as it does when there is a self-signed certificate.<!----></span><br>Chrome just shows a page that will not let you get anywhere and just show the error.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome just shows a page that will not let you get anywhere and just show the error.<!----></span><br><br>This is not the same behaviour in other browsers I have tested with but certainly as a end user I would like to control what happens in this case. <span class="line"><!---->This is not the same behaviour in other browsers I have tested with but certainly as a end user I would like to control what happens in this case. <!----></span><br>Having Chrome show me a serious warning is great. But if Chrome blocks me from doing development then it is a blocker.<span class="line"><!---->Having Chrome show me a serious warning is great.         I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <span class="line"><!---->I believe Chromium is behaving as expected, see <!----></span>https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1"><!---->https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797#section-12.1<!----></a> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <span class="line"><!----> : No user recourse should be possible. i.e. there's no click through option in the interstitial because it is a serious security risk (see the introduction of that RFC). <!----></span><br>There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <span class="line"><!---->There is a way to still click through this interstitial, which is not advertised for obvious reasons (see <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/q/35274659<!----></a> ).<span class="line"><!----> ).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        That is very  disappointing, I added a comment on Stackoverflow but you are basically blocking developers from testing on Chrome. I am currently forced to use Firefox and I cannot test my software on Chrome<span class="line"><!---->That is very  disappointing, I added a comment on Stackoverflow but you are basically blocking developers from testing on Chrome. I am currently forced to use Firefox and I cannot test my software on Chrome<!----></span><br><br>Here is why <span class="line"><!---->Here is why <!----></span><br>1 - Chrome behaves differently from other browsers. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <span class="line"><!---->1 - Chrome behaves differently from other browsers. Firefox does not impose such hideous block and lets "Developers/Users" choose. <!----></span><br>2- you assume developers have always control over their development environments and thus what certificate is used and how it is provisioned. This is not the case. Developers need to allow self-signed certificates or they will just use another browser and will not be able to test local changes on Chrome. <span class="line"><!---->2- you assume developers have always control over their development environments and thus what certificate is used and how it is provisioned. This is not the case. Developers need to allow self-signed certificates or they will just use another browser and will not be able to test local changes on Chrome. <!----></span><br>3 - It is inconsistent that self-signed checks allows users to override them but not for the HSTS one. Why can users just click and ignore self-signed certificates warning when HSTS is disabled vs when it is not?<span class="line"><!---->3 - It is inconsistent that self-signed checks allows users to override them but not for the HSTS one. Why can users just click and ignore self-signed certificates warning when HSTS is disabled vs when it is not?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      
        mr-launch-overview {
          max-width: 100%;
          display: flex;
          flex-flow: column;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          align-items: stretch;
        }
        mr-launch-overview[hidden] {
          display: none;
        }
        mr-phase {
          margin-bottom: 0.75em;
        }
      <style>
        mr-launch-overview {
          max-width: 100%;
          display: flex;
          flex-flow: column;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          align-items: stretch;
        }
        mr-launch-overview[hidden] {
          display: none;
        }
        mr-phase {
          margin-bottom: 0.75em;
        }
      </style>
      
      
    <mr-launch-overview class="main-item" hidden=""><!---->

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
